title: How to Care for Contact Lenses

steps.title: Have clean and dry hands when handling your lenses.
steps.content: Have clean and dry hands when handling your lenses. The first thing to remember is to that you must clean and dry your hands before you put in, or take out, your lenses. Wash your hands thoroughly with mild soap and water before handling your lenses. [1] X Research source Dry your hands with a lint-free towel after washing them. [2] X Research source You don't want any fluff or lint to get into your eyes. If you are putting on makeup, put your lenses in first. Take your lenses out before removing makeup.

steps.title: Gently rub your lenses to clean them.
steps.content: Gently rub your lenses to clean them. You can clean your lenses individually to remove any surface build-up. Squirt a little lens cleaning solution, or multi-purpose solution, into the palm of one hand. Then place the lens in the solution and rub it gently with your index finger. [3] X Research source After rubbing them, rinse them with solution. This "rub and rinse" method is considered very effective. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Take care when you are putting in and taking out your lenses.
steps.content: Take care when you are putting in and taking out your lenses. It's important that don't put in contact lenses that will irritate your eyes. Before you put in a lens, hold it out on your index finger and check for tears or debris. Then carefully place it on the centre of your eye as normal. When you take a lens out , be gentle or you risk tearing it. Check to see if your lens is right side out. You don't want to put on lenses upside down â€” they won't fit correctly and could irritate your eye. If you are struggling to put in or remove your lenses ask for guidance from your eye doctor. If you have long, pointed, or slightly ragged fingernails take extra care not to damage the lens or scratch your eye. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Do not use water or saliva on your lenses.
steps.content: Do not use water or saliva on your lenses. It's very important that you only use the specialized cleaning, storing and disinfecting solutions on your lenses. Also, do not wash or rinse them in water, saliva, or anything else. Micro-organisms in the water can cause infection or even damage your sight. [6] X Research source Do not attempt to rinse your lenses in your mouth, this is asking for an infection. Don't expose your lenses to any kind of water, including bottled, distilled, ocean, lake and tap water. For the same reasons, you should take them out before swimming or getting in a hot tub.

steps.title: Use the correct contact lens solution.
steps.content: Use the correct contact lens solution. Different types of lenses will require the uses of different types of disinfectant solution. It's important to use the correct one for you, so listen to your eye doctor, as well as reading the label on the product you have. [7] X Research source You can use a multi-purpose solution to clean your lenses as well as store them. A saline solution can be used for storing lenses, but not for disinfecting them. If you use a hydrogen peroxide solution, do not put them into your eyes before completing the required process of disinfecting and neutralizing them. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Refill your case with new solution.
steps.content: Refill your case with new solution. Every time you use your lenses you should empty out and refill the case with fresh solution. Do not just top it up, leaving the remaining drops of old solution in the case. Keep it properly refreshed. Remember to close the lid of your bottles of solution after you use them. [9] X Research source Try to avoid touching the top/tip of the contact lens solution bottle to keep it clean. Replace the solution as per the instructions on the bottle. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Optometric Association Professional medical organization dedicated to supporting optometrists and improving public eye and vision health Go to source

steps.title: Clean your contact lens case.
steps.content: Clean your contact lens case. As well as cleaning your hands and lenses, it's important to keep your lens storage case clean and in good condition too. You should rinse it thoroughly with fresh solution after each use. Don't use water for this. [11] X Research source Don't use a towel or cloth to dry your case. After rinsing out your case, leave it open to dry in the air. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Replace the case regularly.
steps.content: Replace the case regularly. You need to keep your case clean, but you will still need to replace it regularly. How often you need to do this will depend on the guidance of your eye doctor and the instructions for the particular product you have. It is, however, recommended that you replace the case every three months. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Don't wear them for longer than you should.
steps.content: Don't wear them for longer than you should. More importantly, do not keep your lenses in for longer than your eye doctor has recommended. Contact your eye doctor directly if you are uncertain how long you can wear a pair of lenses. Your eye doctor can offer you some guidance and even produce a chart so it is easier for you to keep track of the time you have worn your contacts. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Don't sleep in them.
steps.content: Don't sleep in them. If you find yourself drifting off, make sure to remove your lenses before you fall asleep. Leaving them in while you sleep will dry out and irritate your eyes, so it is to be avoided. [15] X Research source There are some lenses designed to be left in while you sleep. Be completely sure that these are the type you have before sleeping in them.

steps.title: Do NOT wear somebody else's lenses.
steps.content: Do NOT wear somebody else's lenses. This sounds obvious, but it's very important not to share your lenses with anybody, no matter what the circumstances. It would be very unhygienic, and could damage your eyes. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Take them out if they irritate your eyes.
steps.content: Take them out if they irritate your eyes. If your lenses are irritating your eyes and causing discomfort, don't just leave them in. Remove them, and don't use them again until you've spoken to your eye doctor. If the lenses are contaminated and you keep wearing them any irritation or infection is likely to remain. [17] X Research source If your eyes have become a little dried out from wearing lenses, take them out and give your eyes a break. You can use re-wetting saline drops to refresh dry eyes.

steps.title: Know when to visit your eye doctor.
steps.content: Know when to visit your eye doctor. You should continue to see your eye doctor for regularly scheduled checks. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Optometric Association Professional medical organization dedicated to supporting optometrists and improving public eye and vision health Go to source But if you experience more serious symptoms it is important to contact your doctor quickly. If you suffer a sudden loss of vision, persistent blurred vision, or light flashes you should act quickly. Other symptoms that you should look out for are: Pain in your eyes. Swelling, or unusual redness. Prolonged irritation or watering. [19] X Research source
